name=armytec /><ref name=nti2 /> }} The '''Arrow''' or '''''Hetz''''' ({{lang-he-n |חֵץ}}, {{IPA-he|ˈχet͡s|pron}}) is a family of [[anti-ballistic missile]]s designed to fulfill an Israeli requirement for a [[missile defense|theater missile defense system]] that would be more effective against [[ballistic missile]]s than the [[MIM-104 Patriot]] [[surface-to-air missile]]. Jointly funded and produced by Israel and the United States, development of the system began in 1986 and has continued since, drawing some contested criticism. Undertaken by [[Israel Aerospace Industries]] (IAI) and [[Boeing]], it is overseen by the [[Ministry of Defense (Israel)|Israeli Ministry of Defense]]'s "''Homa''{{-"}} ({{lang-he|חומה}}, {{IPA-he |χoma|pron}}, "[[Defensive wall|rampart]]") administration and the U.S. [[Missile Defense Agency]].
The Arrow system consists of the joint production [[hypersonic]] Arrow anti-missile interceptor, the [[Elta]] [[EL/M-2080 Green Pine|EL/M-2080]] "Green Pine" [[Early warning radar|early-warning]] [[Active Electronically Scanned Array|AESA]] [[radar]], the [[Elisra]] "Golden Citron" ("Citron Tree") [[C4ISTAR|C<sup>3</sup>I]] center, and the [[Israel Aerospace Industries]] "Brown Hazelnut" ("Hazelnut Tree") launch control center. The system is transportable, as it can be moved to other prepared sites.
Following the construction and testing of the Arrow 1 technology demonstrator, production and deployment began with the Arrow 2 version of the missile. The Arrow is considered one of the most advanced missile defense programs currently in existence.<ref name = mstrt>{{cite web |url= http://missilethreat.com/missiledefensesystems/id.10/system_detail.asp |publisher= [[Claremont Institute]] | work = Missile Threat | title = Missile defense systems: Arrow |accessdate = 2009-08-19 }}{{dead link|date=August 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref><ref name ="jewish">{{cite web |url= https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/US-Israel/Arrow.html | publisher = [[Jewish Virtual Library]] | title = The Arrow missile program | accessdate = 2009-08-21}}</ref> It is the first operational missile defense system specifically designed and built to intercept and destroy ballistic missiles.<ref name=nti>{{cite web|url=http://www.nti.org/e_research/profiles/Israel/Missile/ |publisher=[[Nuclear Threat Initiative]] |title=Israel profile: missile overview: Arrow anti-ballistic missile defense system |date=October 2008 |accessdate=2009-08-19 }}{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref name = aipac>{{cite web | url= http://www.aipac.org/~/media/Publications/Policy%20and%20Politics/AIPAC%20Analyses/Issue%20Memos/2006/12/U_S_Israel_Missile_Defense_Cooperation.pdf | format = PDF |publisher= [[American Israel Public Affairs Committee]] |title = U.S.–Israel missile defense cooperation | date = 2006-12-21 | accessdate = 2011-08-04}}</ref> The first Arrow battery was declared fully operational in October 2000. Although several of its components have been exported, the [[Israeli Air Defense Command]] within the [[Israeli Air Force]] (IAF) of the [[Israel Defense Forces]] (IDF) is currently the sole user of the complete Arrow system.
==Background== {{See also|Arab–Israeli conflict}} The Arrow program was launched in light of the acquisition by [[Arab League|Arab states]] of long ranged [[surface-to-surface missile]]s.<ref name=iafkg>{{cite web | publisher = [[Israeli Air Force]] | title= Israel Aircraft Industries 'Arrow' ('Hetz') | url = http://www.iaf.org.il/907-18137-EN/IAF.aspx | accessdate = 2010-08-01}}</ref><ref name=dtic /> It was chosen over [[Rafael Advanced Defense Systems|RAFAEL Armament Development Authority]]'s AB-10 missile defense system since the Arrow was judged to be a more complete concept and have greater range. The AB-10 system was criticized as being merely an improved [[MIM-23 Hawk]], rather than a system designed from the outset for missile interception.<ref name=nti0>{{cite web|url=http://www.nti.org/db/missile/1998/m9808247.htm |publisher=[[Nuclear Threat Initiative]] |title=The big arrow In Israel's quiver |date=1998-10-05 |accessdate=2011-02-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727133602/http://www.nti.org/db/missile/1998/m9808247.htm |archivedate=July 27, 2011 }}</ref>
The United States and Israel signed a [[memorandum of understanding]] to co-fund the Arrow program on May 6, 1986,<ref name="global" /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.policyalmanac.org/world/archive/crs_israeli-us_relations.shtml |last=Clyde |first= Mark R. | work = Almanac of Policy Issues |title=Israeli–United States relations |date= 2002-10-17 | accessdate=2009-08-19}}</ref> and in 1988 the [[United States Department of Defense]] [[Strategic Defense Initiative|Strategic Defense Initiative Organization]] (SDIO) placed an order with Israel Aircraft Industries for the Arrow 1 technology demonstrator.<ref name="armytec">{{cite web | work = Army technology | title = Arrow 2 theater ballistic missile defense system, Israel | url = http://www.army-technology.com/projects/arrow2/ | accessdate= 2009-08-19}}</ref><ref name=global/><ref name=tests/><ref group="Note">Over the years SDIO was renamed to [[Ballistic Missile Defense Organization]] (BMDO), and later to Missile Defense Agency (MDA), while Israel Aircraft Industries was renamed to [[Israel Aerospace Industries]].</ref> The [[Gulf War]], which exposed the controversial performance<ref name= "fas_patriot">{{Cite journal | url = https://fas.org/spp/starwars/congress/1992_h/ | title = The performance of the Patriot missile in the Gulf| author1-link= Theodore Postol |first1= Theodore | last1 = Postol | first2= Reuven |last2= Pedatzur | first3 = Charles |last3 = Zraket |author4-link = Peter Zimmerman |first4= Peter |last4= Zimmerman | publisher = [[Federation of American Scientists]]| date = 1992-04-07 | postscript = <!--None-->}}. Retrieved 2009-10-09.</ref> of the [[MIM-104 Patriot|Patriot missile]] against [[Iraq]]i "[[Al Hussein (missile)|Al Hussein]]" missiles, gave further impetus to the development of the Arrow.<ref name=iafkg/> It was initially designed to intercept missiles such as the [[Scud|SS-1 "Scud"]], its "Al Hussein" derivative, the [[OTR-21 Tochka|SS-21 "Scarab"]] operated by [[Syria]], and the [[Dongfeng (missile)#Dongfeng 3 (CSS-2)|CSS-2]] operated by [[Saudi Arabia]].<ref name=dtic /> The Arrow evolved also with an eye on the advanced missile programs of [[Iran]]. [[Yitzhak Rabin]], then [[Yitzhak Rabin#Opposition Knesset member and Minister of Defense|Defense Minister of Israel]], viewed the emerging missile threat as one of the most dangerous future threats on Israel's security.<ref name="inss" /> He said of the program that: {{cquote|I had the honor, during my term of office as Minister of Defense, in the [[National Unity Government#Israel|National Unity Government]], to vote in favor of Israel's participation in the Strategic Defense Initiative... introduced by [[Ronald Reagan|President Reagan]]...<ref name="tests" />}} The Israeli [[Administration for the Development of Weapons and Technological Infrastructure]], part of the [[Ministry of Defense (Israel)|Israeli Ministry of Defense]], runs the Arrow development project under the ''"Homa"'' administration. The ''"Homa"'' administration, which is also commonly referred to as the IMDO – Israel Missile Defense Organization, is responsible for coordinating industrial activities of Israel's different defense companies involved in the development of the Arrow system.<ref name="tests"/><ref name="haalong"/>
===Funding=== {{See also|Israel – United States military relations}} The multibillion-dollar development program of the Arrow is undertaken in Israel with the financial support of the United States. When the development program began, the projection for the total cost of its development and manufacture – including the initial production of missiles – was an estimated $1.6 billion.<ref name="haalong" /> The price of a single Arrow missile was estimated at $3 million.<ref name="haalong" /> Between 1989 and 2007 some $2.4 billion had been reportedly invested in the Arrow program, 50–80<ref name="a3-80">{{cite web |url=http://defense-update.com/newscast/0808/0709_arrow-3.html |publisher=''[http://www.defense-update.com/about.htm Defense Update]'' |title=Israel asks U.S. to support Arrow-3 | accessdate=2009-08-19}}</ref> percent of which was funded by the [[federal government of the United States|United States]].<ref name="defup">{{cite web | title = Israel's strategic defense programs | publisher = ''[http://www.defense-update.com/about.htm Defense Update]'' | date = 2007-03-01 | accessdate=2009-08-19 | url = http://www.defense-update.com/features/du-2-06/feature-ILmissiledefense.htm}}</ref> Israel contributes approximately $65 million annually.<ref name="haalong">{{cite web | title = An Arrow to the heart | publisher = ''[[Haaretz]]'' | first=Amnon |last= Barzilai | accessdate=2009-09-18 | url = http://www.haaretz.com/misc/article-print-page/an-arrow-to-the-heart-1.28321?trailingPath=2.169%2C}}</ref>

===Criticism and opposition=== The Arrow program encountered opposition from the IAF, whose traditional doctrine of deterrence and use of preemptive strikes stand in sharp contrast with the nature of the missile. In addition, the IAF feared that the procurement of the costly missiles would diminish the resources allocated towards offensive projects such as fighter aircraft.<ref>{{Cite journal |first=Duncan L.|last=Clarke|jstor=4328717 |title=The Arrow Missile: The United States, Israel and Strategic Cooperation |journal=Middle East Journal |publisher=Middle East Institute |volume=48 |issue=3 |page=478 |date=Summer 1994 |subscription=yes }}</ref>
A criticism of the concept of missile defense for Israel was aired by Dr. [[Reuven Pedatzur]] in a comprehensive study<ref name="peda">{{Cite book |isbn=965-459-005-0 |publisher= Jaffee Center for Strategic Studies |place = [[Tel Aviv University]] |title=The Arrow project and active defense – challenges and questions | type = paper | number =42 |first= Reuven |last=Pedatzur |date=October 1993}}</ref> published in 1993 by the Jaffee Center for Strategic Studies.<ref group="Note">Forerunner of the [[Institute for National Security Studies (Israel)|Institute for National Security Studies]] (INSS).</ref> The arguments made in the study conformed to the opinions of numerous defense officials and analysts, and echoed many of the arguments made by the [[Strategic Defense Initiative]] critics in the United States.<ref name= "inss">{{cite web | place = IL | url = http://www.inss.org.il/upload/%28FILE%291216205936.pdf |format=PDF | pages = 67–69, 75–77 |publisher=[[Institute for National Security Studies (Israel)|Institute for National Security Studies]] |title = Missile defense and Israel's deterrence against a nuclear Iran |first=Uzi |last=Rubin |authorlink= Uzi Rubin |year=2008 |accessdate = 2009-08-25}}</ref>
Pedatzur argued that it was exceedingly simple to fool an Arrow-type defensive system with simple, cheap, and easily installed countermeasures, which would render the Arrow system ineffective. He doubted Israel's defense industries could rise to the challenge of such a complex system, citing anonymous experts in the IDF who predicted that the system would not be available before 2010. He envisaged enormous costs, around $10 billion,<ref name = "haalong" /> that would distort budgeting priorities and divert funds from the vital enhancement of the IDF's warfighting capability, thus forcing a profound revision of Israel's national security doctrine. He further argued that even if effective against missiles with [[conventional warfare|conventional]], [[Chemical warfare|chemical]] or [[Biological warfare|biological]] [[warhead]]s, the Arrow would not be relevant against future threats of missiles with [[Nuclear weapon|nuclear]] warheads, since it would never be able to supply hermetic defense and the impact of even a single nuclear warhead in Israel's [[Population density|densely populated]] [[urban area]] would be an existential threat to Israel.<ref name=dtic /><ref name="inss" />
At the same time, [[John E. Pike]], who worked then with the [[Federation of American Scientists]], stated that "given technical problems with the systems radar and command system, coupled with its high development cost, the Arrow program may soon fall by the wayside".<ref>{{cite web | last1 = Pike | first1 = John E | author1-link = John E. Pike | last2 = Bolkcom | first2 = Christopher | title = 3. Air defense effectiveness | website = [https://fas.org/spp/aircraft/ Attack Aircraft. Proliferation: Issues for Concern] | publisher = [[Federation of American Scientists]] | date = 1993{{ndash}}96 | url = https://fas.org/spp/aircraft/part03.htm | accessdate = 2015-02-20}}</ref> Victoria Samson, a [[research associate]] of the [[Center for Defense Information]], also stated in October 2002 that the Arrow system cannot track an incoming missile that has split its warhead into [[Multiple independently targetable reentry vehicle|submunitions]].<ref name = "cdi">{{cite web |url=http://www.cdi.org/missile-defense/arrow.cfm |publisher= [[Center for Defense Information]] | title = Israel's Arrow missile defense: not ready for prime time |first= Victoria |last = Samson |date = 2002-10-09 | accessdate = 2009-10-13| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090906184042/http://www.cdi.org/missile%2Ddefense/arrow.cfm | archivedate= 6 September 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
In June 2003 a group of Israeli chief engineers, co-inventors, and project managers of IAI and subcontractors were awarded the [[Israel Defense Prize]] for the development and production of the Arrow system.<ref name= "prize">{{cite web |url=http://www.iai.co.il/28973-25365-he/default.aspx?PageNum=4 |publisher=[[Israel Aerospace Industries]] | trans_title = Israel Defense Prize for 2003 to developers and directors of the Arrow weapon system | script-title=he:פרס ביטחון ישראל לשנת 2003 למפתחי ומנהלי מערכת נשק חץ |language= he |accessdate=2010-03-20 |date = 2003-07-03}}</ref>
According to Dr. [[Uzi Rubin]], first Director of IMDO, with the passage of time most of the pessimistic predictions have proven to be unfounded. Israel's defense industries overcame the technical challenge, the system's development was completed a full decade ahead of what was predicted, and there are no indications that the expenditures for the Arrow harmed other IDF procurement plans to any degree whatsoever.<ref name="inss" /> Rubin insists that Israel's missile defense is now an established fact and that most of the warnings issued by critics have failed to materialize.<ref name= "inss" /> Pedatzur, however, remained unconvinced.<ref name = "peda3" /><ref name="peda2">{{cite web |url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1065134.html | work = Haaretz | title = It's possible to live with Iran |first= Reuven |last= Pedatzur |date = 2009-02-18 |accessdate = 2009-08-25}}</ref>
==Development== [[File:Arrow Missile Model II.JPG|thumb|upright|right|alt=A mockup of the Arrow 1, at the Technion – Israel Institute of Technology. |A [[mockup]] of the Arrow 1, near the [[Technion – Israel Institute of Technology|Technion's]] [[Technion Faculty of Aerospace Engineering|Faculty of Aerospace Engineering]].]]
===Arrow 1=== The first launch of the Arrow interceptor took place on August 9, 1990, designed to test the missile's control and guidance systems. The test came to a halt seconds after take off and the missile was intentionally destroyed due to fears it might go off track and hit a settled location. This was caused by the failure of the ground tracking radars to track the missile's [[trajectory]].<ref name=iafkg/> Test number two took place on March 25, 1991. Designed to check missile components during launch, it was conducted from a ship at sea. Once again a missile malfunction resulted in the abortion of the experiment.<ref name=iafkg/> A third test, designed to examine the Arrow's interception capabilities, was conducted on October 31, 1991. The missile was once again launched from a ship at sea, and was once more aborted because of a repeat of previous malfunctions.<ref name=iafkg/>
On September 23, 1992, in another test of the missile components during launch, the systems finally operated as planned and the Arrow reached its designated point in the sky, 45 seconds after launch. As planned, the missile was then destroyed. This successful experiment ended the system's preliminary testing phase.<ref name=iafkg/> The fifth, sixth, and seventh tests took place on February 28, July 14, and October 14, 1993 respectively. During these, the Arrow managed to pass in close proximity to the target missiles, thereby proving its ability to intercept surface-to-surface missiles.<ref name=iafkg/> During test number eight on March 1, 1994, the missile was not launched due to a ground computer failure.<ref name=iafkg/> The ninth test launch on June 12, 1994, also known as ATD#1 (Arrow Demonstration Test 1), saw an Arrow 1 successfully intercepted a target missile launched from a ship anchored in the middle of the [[Mediterranean Sea|Mediterranean]].<ref name=iafkg/><ref name=tests>{{cite web|publisher=Israel Missile Defense Organization |title=Story of the Arrow weapon system |url=http://www.mod.gov.il/pages/homa/bg.htm |accessdate=2009-08-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090908222327/http://www.mod.gov.il:80/pages/homa/bg.htm |archivedate=2009-09-08 |df= }}</ref>
The Arrow 1 was reportedly a two-stage [[solid propellant]] missile, with an overall length of {{convert|7.5|m|ft|abbr=on}}, a body diameter of {{convert|1200|mm|in|abbr=on}}, and a launch weight of around {{convert|2000|kg|abbr=on}}. It was estimated that the second stage had a length of {{convert|2.5|m|ft|abbr=on}}, and that it had [[Inertial navigation system|inertial]] and [[Missile guidance#Command Off Line-Of-Sight (COLOS)|command update mid-course]] guidance, with a terminal [[Infrared homing|infrared]] [[focal plane]] array. The missile was described as being relatively high-speed and maneuverable, with [[thrust vectoring]] in the both stages. The range capability has been described as around {{convert|50|km|mi|abbr=on}}.<ref name=nti2>{{cite web |url=http://www.nti.org/media/pdfs/israel_missile.pdf?_=1316466791 |publisher=[[Nuclear Threat Initiative]] |title=Israel profile: Missile overview: Missile Chronology |format=PDF |date=January 2010 |accessdate=2012-04-03}}</ref> On the other hand, the Arrow 1 could be a single stage missile.<ref name="stav" /> Development of the "big and cumbersome"<ref name="uzi" /> Arrow 1 then ceased and further research continued with the "smaller, faster and more lethal" Arrow 2.<ref name=iafkg/><ref name=tests/>
===Arrow 2=== {{double image|right|Arrow2 96feb.jpg|320|Arrow2 96aug.jpg|200|Arrow 2 launch in February 1996.|Arrow 2 launch in August 1996.|Arrow 2 launch in February 1996.|Arrow 2 launch in August 1996.}} Two successful tests (designated IIT#21 and IIT#22) of the steering, control and cruising systems were conducted without target missiles on July 30, 1995 and February 20, 1996.<ref name=iafkg/><ref name=tests/> Two successful interceptions took place on August 20, 1996 and March 11, 1997, and were designated AIT#21 and AIT#22.<ref name=iafkg/><ref name=tests/> Another interception test (AIT#23) was conducted on August 20, 1997, but the missile was destroyed when its steering system malfunctioned.<ref name="iafkg" /><ref name="tests" /> The fault was corrected in time to ensure the success of AST#3,<ref name=iafkg/><ref name=tests/> the first comprehensive test of the entire system. On September 14, 1998, all system components successfully countered a computer-simulated threat.<ref name=iafkg/><ref name=tests/> On November 29, 1998, Israel Aerospace Industries delivered the first operational Arrow 2 interceptor to the Israeli Ministry of Defense.<ref name="tests" />
A full system interception test (AST#4) was held on November 1, 1999. During this test the Arrow system located, tracked and intercepted a TM-91C target missile simulating a "Scud" missile, launched on a very steep trajectory from a ship located offshore.<ref name=tests/><ref name=AST4-5-8-10/> The IAI TM-91C target missile was itself based on the Arrow 1 interceptor.<ref name=targets/> On March 14, 2000, the first complete Arrow 2 battery was rolled out in a ceremony at [[Palmachim Airbase]].<ref name=tests/> In his speech, then IAF commander [[Aluf]] [[Eitan Ben Eliyahu]] said: {{cquote |This is a great day for the Air Defense Forces, for the Air Force, the defense establishment and, I would say, for the State of Israel. As of today, we have completed the acceptance of the only weapon system of its kind in the entire world. We are the first to succeed in developing, building and operating a defense system against ballistic missiles.<ref name="tests" />}}
Another Arrow 2 test (AST#5) took place on September 14, 2000, this time with a new target missile, the [[Rafael Advanced Defense Systems]] "[[Sparrow target missile|Black Sparrow]]".<ref name="rafspar" /> This airborne ballistic target missile, launched by an IAF [[F-15 Eagle|F-15]] towards Israel's coastline at a ballistic trajectory simulating an aggressor "Scud", was intercepted and destroyed.<ref name="iafkg" /><ref name = AST4-5-8-10 /> Consequently, the following month saw the Palmachim Arrow battery declared operational by the Israeli Air Defense Command.<ref name=tests/> The "Black Sparrow" has since been used as the aggressor target in the AST#6, AST#9, and AST#10 tests.<ref name = targets>{{cite web |url = http://www.mod.gov.il/pages/homa/tm91c.htm | title =TM-91C target missile}} {{cite web |url=http://www.mod.gov.il/pages/homa/blackSp.htm | publisher = Israel Missile Defense Organization |title= "Black Sparrow" target missile| accessdate=2009-08-19}}</ref> Reportedly, in June 2001 Arrow missiles were test-fired in the course of a joint American-Israeli-Turkish exercise code-named [[Anatolian Eagle]], in the southeast of [[Turkey]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ca-c.org/online/2004/journal_eng/cac-01/1%2825%29.2004.pdf |format= PDF | publisher =Center for Social and Political Studies |title=Central Asia and the Caucasus: Journal of Social and Political Studies| page=64 |date=January 2004 |accessdate=2011-11-21}}</ref> On August 27, 2001 (AST#6), the Arrow system successfully intercepted its target at some {{convert|100|km|mi|abbr=on}} from shore, the highest and farthest that the Arrow 2 had been tested to date.<ref name=iafkg/><ref name = global>{{cite web |url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/space/systems/arrow.htm |first= John E |last= Pike |authorlink = John E. Pike | work = Global Security |title=Arrow theater missile defense |accessdate=2009-08-19| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090805232642/http://www.globalsecurity.org/space/systems/arrow.htm| archivedate= 5 August 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> In October 2002 the second battery was declared operational.<ref name=tests/>
====Block-2==== {{triple image|right|Arrow anti-ballistic missile launch4.jpg|200|Arrow anti-ballistic missile launch3.jpg|200|Arrow anti-ballistic missile launch2.jpg|200|Arrow 2 launch on August 26, 2004, during AST USFT#2.|||Arrow 2 launch on August 26, 2004, during AST USFT#2.|Arrow 2 launch on August 26, 2004, during AST USFT#2.|Arrow 2 launch on August 26, 2004, during AST USFT#2.}} A successful test of the Arrow 2 block-2 took place on January 5, 2003 (AST#8). Four missiles were launched towards four simulated targets in order to examine the interceptor's performance during special flight conditions as well as system performance during a sequence of launches.<ref name= iafkg/><ref name=AST4-5-8-10 /> The test did not include actual interceptions.<ref name= iafkg /> Another successful test held on December 16, 2003 (AST#9), examined the system's ability to intercept and destroy incoming missiles at significantly high altitudes,<ref name=tests/> around {{convert|60|km|mi|abbr=on}}.<ref name=mstrt /> Reportedly, AST#8 and AST#9 also tested integration of the Arrow with Patriot batteries.<ref name=iafkg/><ref name=tests />
On July 29, 2004, Israel and the United States carried out a joint test at the [[Naval Air Station Point Mugu]] (NAS [[Point Mugu]]) Missile Test Center in [[California]], in which the Arrow interceptor was launched against a real "Scud-B" missile. The test represented a realistic scenario that could not have been tested in Israel due to test-field safety restrictions.<ref name=global /> To enable the test a full battery was shipped to Point Mugu. The "Green Pine" radar and [[Command and control (military)|command-and-control]] systems were deployed at the base, while the Arrow launcher was installed {{convert |100|km|mi|abbr = on}} offshore on an island that forms part of the test range.<ref name = "Egozi">{{cite web | url = http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2004/08/03/185346/arrow-destroys-scud-b-target-in-us-ballistic-missile-test.html | work = [[Flightglobal.com|Flight global]] |title=Arrow destroys Scud-B target in US ballistic-missile test |first=Arie |last= Egozi |date = 2004-08-03 |accessdate = 2009-09-12}}</ref> The test was a success, with the interceptor destroying the "Scud" that flew a {{convert|300|km|mi|abbr=on}} trajectory<ref name="Egozi" /> at an altitude of {{convert |40|km|mi| abbr=on}},<ref name= armytec/><ref name=asro>{{cite web | work = [[Encyclopedia Astronautica]] | title= Arrow | url = http://www.astronautix.com/lvs/arrow.htm | accessdate=2009-09-21}}</ref><ref name="mdaa2"/> west of [[San Nicolas Island]].<ref name="mdalink">{{cite web |url=http://www.mda.mil/global/documents/pdf/04fyi0013.pdf |publisher=Missile Defense Agency |date=2004-06-29 |format=PDF |title=MDA/Israeli Arrow flight test successful |accessdate=2009-11-04}}</ref> This was the twelfth Arrow interceptor test and the seventh test of the complete system, the first interception of a real "Scud".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mod.gov.il/pages/homa/testUS1.htm |publisher=Israel Missile Defense Organization |title=Arrow system test USFT#1| accessdate=2009-08-19}}</ref> This significant test became known as the AST USFT#1.<ref name="tests" /> Following this test, then [[Defense Minister of Israel]], [[Shaul Mofaz]], said: {{cquote|We are in an age of uncertainty. Countries in the 'third circle' [Iran] are continuing their efforts to acquire non-conventional capabilities along with long-ranged launch capabilities. The Arrow is the best missile system of its kind in the world, and represents a force multiplier for our future force.<ref name= "ido">{{cite web |url=http://www.isracast.com/article.aspx?id=100 |title= The Arrow missile scores a direct hit| work = Isracast |date=2004-08-10 |accessdate=2009-08-19 |first=Iddo |last= Genuth}}</ref>}}
AST USFT#2 was conducted at NAS Point Mugu a month later, on August 26. This test was aimed at examining the Arrow's ability to detect a splitting warhead of a separating ballistic missile.<ref name=armytec/><ref name = "mdaa2">{{cite web |url = http://www.missiledefenseadvocacy.org/web/page/746/sectionid/557/pagelevel/4/interior.aspx |publisher=[[Missile Defense Advocacy Alliance]] |title=Ground based interceptor Arrow-2 | accessdate =2009-10-12}}</ref> It detected the true target, but a technical malfunction reportedly prevented it from maneuvering to strike it,<ref name="passes">{{cite web |url=http://www.jinsa.org/node/565 |publisher = [[Jewish Institute for National Security Affairs]] |title= Arrow passes toughest test yet |accessdate = 2009-08-19}}</ref> leading to a suspension of testing.<ref name="armytec" /><ref name="mdaa2"/> In March–April 2005 the ability of "Green Pine" and "Golden Citron" to work with Patriot system elements operated by [[United States Army|U.S. Army]] was successfully tested against simulated "Scud"-type targets during regular series of U.S.–Israeli biennial exercises code-named "[[Juniper Cobra]]".<ref name= tests /><ref name = opalrome>{{cite web | url = http://www.spacenews.com/archive/archive05/IsraelMD_031405.html |publisher= [[Imaginova]] | work = Space News |title= Israel, U.S. test compatibility of Arrow-Patriot interceptors |first= Barbara |last= Opall-Rome | date = 2005-03-14 |accessdate=2009-10-10}}</ref> Actual testing of the complete Arrow system was resumed in December 2005, when the system successfully intercepted a target at an unspecified but reported record low altitude.<ref name=armytec/><ref name="mdaa2"/> This test (AST#10) was the fourteenth test of the Arrow missile and the ninth test of the complete system.<ref name=AST4-5-8-10>{{cite web |url= http://www.mod.gov.il/pages/homa/at.htm |title = Arrow system test #4}} {{cite web | url = http://www.mod.gov.il/pages/homa/test05.htm | title = Arrow system test #5}} {{cite web |url=http://www.mod.gov.il/pages/homa/test08.htm |title= Arrow system test #8}} {{cite web |url=http://www.mod.gov.il/pages/homa/test10.htm |publisher= Israel Missile Defense Circa 2006–2007.|Arrow 2 on display at [[Rishon LeZion]] in September 2008|Arrow 2 launcher. Circa 2006–2007.|Arrow 2 on display at Rishon LeZion in September 2008}} On February 11, 2007 an Arrow 2 block-3<ref name=sipri>{{cite book| author=[[Stockholm International Peace Research Institute]]| title =SIPRI yearbook 2008: armaments, disarmament, and international security | publisher = [[Oxford University Press]]| year = 2008 |page= 413 | isbn = 978-0-19-954895-8 |url = https://books.google.com/?id=EAyQ9KCJE2gC |accessdate=2009-09-12}}</ref> successfully intercepted and destroyed a "Black Sparrow" target missile simulating a ballistic missile at high altitude.<ref name=armytec/><ref name="mdaa2"/> It was the first so-called distributed weapon system test conducted in Israel, which required two Arrow units deployed some {{convert|100|km|mi|abbr=on}} apart to share data on incoming threats and coordinate launching assignments. It was also the first time the [[Link 16]] data distribution system was used to connect two Arrow units, although the system had been used in previous tests to connect Arrow and Patriot batteries.<ref name="passes"/> Furthermore, an improved launcher was used.<ref name="mda2" /> Another "Juniper Cobra" exercises ran from March 10 to 20, 2007. The computer simulation used for "Juniper Cobra 2007" was similar to the computer simulation used in "Juniper Cobra 2005".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.army.mil/-news/2007/03/21/2349-usareur-units-participate-in-juniper-cobra-2007/ |publisher=[[United States Department of Defense]] |first=John |last= Queen |title=USAREUR units participate in Juniper Cobra 2007 |date=2007-03-21 |accessdate=2009-10-10<!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
A precursor of the next block was launched without a target on March 26, 2007 in order to gather information on its flight and performance,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/842111.html |publisher=''Haaretz'' |first=Amos |last= Harel |title=Anti-missile exercise tests electronics of Arrow system |date=2007-03-26 |accessdate=2009-08-19}}</ref> introducing unspecified modifications to its hardware and [[electronics]] and reduced manufacturing costs by some 20 percent.<ref name="blk4">{{cite web |url=http://www.jpost.com/Home/Article.aspx?id=56027 |publisher=''[[The Jerusalem Post]]'' |title=IAF launches new 'cheap' Arrow |first=Yaakov |last= Katz |date=2007-03-26 |accessdate=2010-07-27}}</ref> [[Arieh Herzog]], then Director of IMDO, has said: "Our Arrow operational system can without a doubt deal with all of the operational threats in the [[Middle East]], particularly in Iran and Syria."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jpost.com/Home/Article.aspx?id=56544 |first=Yaakov |last= Katz |publisher=''[[The Jerusalem Post]]'' |title=Arrow can fully protect against Iran |date=2007-03-30 |accessdate=2010-07-27}}</ref>
====Block-4==== On April 15, 2008 the Arrow weapon system successfully detected and made a simulated intercept of a new target missile,<ref name= armytec /><ref name= blues1 /> the "[[Sparrow target missile|Blue Sparrow]]", a successor of the "Black Sparrow" capable of simulating "Scud-C/D" missiles<ref name="rafspar">{{cite web |url = http://www.rafael.co.il/marketing/SIP_STORAGE/FILES/2/622.pdf |format=PDF |publisher=[[Rafael Advanced Defense Systems]] |title=Sparrow targets brochure |accessdate=2009-08-19}}</ref> and reportedly the [[Iran]]ian [[Shahab-3]] as well.<ref name= armytec /><ref name = blues1 /> During the test, a target missile was launched from an IAF F-15 at a height of 90,000 feet (27.5 km). The missile split into [[Multiple independently targetable reentry vehicle|multiple warheads]], making it harder to intercept it.<ref name= blues1 /> Nevertheless, "Green Pine" tracked the warhead, simulating an intercept.<ref name = blues1>{{cite web |url = http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/975269.html |first= Amos |last= Harel | work = Haaretz |title= Arrow successfully simulates intercept of mock Shihab missile |date=2008-04-15 |accessdate=2009-08-26}}</ref> In September 2008 the IDF attempted a test of actual Arrow 2 block-4 missile against the "Blue Sparrow". The drill had to be aborted, however, when the target missile malfunctioned shortly after launch.<ref name = fox>{{cite web | url = http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,512970,00.html |publisher=[[Fox News]] | agency = [[Associated Press]] | title =Israel successfully tests anti-missile system to protect against Iran |date=2009-04-07 | accessdate = 2009-08-19}}</ref> Eventually the Arrow 2 block-4 was successfully tested against the "Blue Sparrow" on April 7, 2009.<ref name=fox/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iai.co.il/32981-39454-en/ |publisher= [[Israel Aerospace Industries]] |title=Improved Arrow missile destroys target in latest test of the system |date = 2009-04-07 | accessdate =2009-08-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.jpost.com/Home/Article.aspx?id=138494 | first = Yaakov |last= Katz | work = [[The Jerusalem Post]] |title = Israel successfully tests Arrow 2 defense system | date =2009-04-07 |accessdate= 2010-07-27}}</ref>
[[File:Arrow2 2011feb 1.jpg|thumb|upright|Arrow 2 launch in February 2011.|alt=Arrow 2 launch in February 2011.]] A July 22, 2009, joint test of the Arrow 2 block-4 against an airborne target missile with a range of over {{convert |1000|km|mi|abbr=on}} once again at the NAS Point Mugu,<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.reuters.com/article/latestCrisis/idUSN14292699 |publisher=[[Reuters]] |first= David |last= Morgan |title= Israel to test Arrow missile on U.S. Pacific range |accessdate= 2009-08-19 |date= 2009-07-14}}</ref> was reportedly aborted in the final second before launch after the missile failed to establish a communications link.<ref name= "last">{{cite web |url=http://www.defense-update.com/newscast/0709/news/arrow_2_test_230709.html | work = Defense Update | title = Arrow-II aborts long-range intercept Test | date = 2009-07-23 |accessdate=2009-08-19}}</ref><ref name=opalrome2/> A target had been released from a [[C-17 Globemaster III]] aircraft,<ref name="mdaa" /><ref name= "mda" /> the radar detected the target and transferred its tracks,<ref name="last" /> but the interceptor was not launched.<ref name="mdaa">{{cite web |url = http://missiledefense.wordpress.com/2009/07/23/arrow-missile-defense-fails-test/ |publisher=[[Missile Defense Advocacy Alliance]] |title=Arrow missile defense fails test |date=2009-07-23 |accessdate=2009-08-25}}</ref> "Tracking of the target worked well, but tracking trajectory information that the radar transferred to the battle management center erroneously showed we would be out of the prescribed safety range, so the mission was aborted," a program source said.<ref name=block5>{{cite web |url = http://www.defensenews.com/story.php?i=4548013&c=FEA&s=SPE | work = [[Defense News]] |title= Iran threat speeds Arrow-3 effort |first = Barbara |last = Opall-Rome | date =2010-03-22 |accessdate=2010-03-22}}</ref> The aborted interception came after two earlier setbacks in the planned test, initially scheduled for July 17. The first try was scuttled due to a technical glitch in the C-17 aircraft, and a planned July 20 attempt was scrubbed due to a malfunctioning [[Battery (electricity)|electric battery]] that was not providing enough power to a key element of the Arrow system.<ref name =opalrome2>{{cite web |url=http://www.spacenews.com/archive/archive09/arrowtest_0727.html | publisher = Imaginova | work = Space News |title= Aborted Arrow intercept test may postpone August demo | first= Barbara | last = Opall-Rome |date=2009-07-29 |accessdate=2009-10-10}}</ref> The test was widely referred to as a failure,<ref name="peda3">{{cite web |url = http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1103395.html | work = Haaretz | title = Even if the Hetz succeeds |first= Reuven |last= Pedatzur |accessdate=2009-08-25}}</ref><ref name= "mdaa" /> however objectives of interoperability with other ballistic missile defense systems were achieved.<ref name = "mda">{{cite web |url=http://www.mda.mil/news/09news0014.html |publisher=Missile Defense Agency |title= Missile defense test conducted|date=2009-11-04 |accessdate=2009-08-19}}</ref>
On February 22, 2011 the Arrow system successfully intercepted a long-range<ref name=block4-2011/> ballistic target missile during a flight test conducted at NAS Point Mugu. The target missile was launched from a mobile launch platform off the coast of California, within the Point Mugu test range.<ref name= "mda2011">{{cite web | url = http://www.mda.mil/news/11news0002.html |publisher=Missile Defense Agency |title=Joint U.S.-Israel Arrow weapon system intercepts target during successful missile defense test|date=2011-02-22 |accessdate= 2011-02-22}}</ref> The test validated new block-4 versions designed to improve discriminating capabilities of the Arrow 2 interceptor.<ref name=block4-2011>{{cite web |url=http://www.defensenews.com/story.php?i=5777664 | work = [[Defense News]] |title=Arrow test hits target, validates new software |first=Barbara |last= Opall-Rome |date = 2011-02-25 | accessdate = 2011-04-18}}</ref> It was a body-to-body impact that completely destroyed the target.<ref name=block4-2011 />
On February 10, 2012 developers successfully conducted the final target-tracking test prior to delivery of block-4 Arrow system. The Blue Sparrow target missile was detected and tracked by the radar, the intercept solutions were plotted by the battle management controller and transferred to the launch units.<ref name= "bl4">{{cite web | url = http://defense-update.com/20120210_super_gereen_pine_bms_test-2.html | work = Defense Update |first= Tamir |last=Eshel |title=Israel tests Arrow 2 block 4 ATBM with Super Green Pine radar |date=2012-02-10 |accessdate= 2012-02-11}}</ref>
According to [[Arieh Herzog]], block-4 upgrades "improve the process of discrimination of what happens in the sky and the transmission of target data for much better situational control."<ref name= block4-2011 /> Block-4 upgrades also refine midcourse guidance which, when coupled with improved target identification and discrimination capabilities, improves lethality.<ref name=block4-2011 />
Block-4.1 is expected to include a new Battle Management Center, armored launchers with high shooting availability, better communication with other missile systems and wider ranges of interceptions.<ref name = blk4.1>{{cite web | publisher = [[Israeli Air Force]] | title= Arrow missiles to undergo major overhaul | url = http://www.iaf.org.il/4392-40415-en/IAF.aspx | date=2013-02-04 |accessdate= 2013-02-04}}</ref> On September 9, 2014 an intercept test was conducted over the Mediterranean Sea with block-4.1 versions of the operational system. The outcome was inconclusive and remained so until data was fully analyzed.<ref name = block4.1>{{cite web |url = http://www.defensenews.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=2014309090032 | work = [[Defense News]] |title= Arrow-2 intercept test inconclusive, Israel says. Will take days to review data |first = Barbara |last = Opall-Rome | date =2014-09-09 | accessdate=2014-09-14}}</ref> In February 2015, an official at the IMDO acknowledged that a test successfully acquired, but narrowly missed its target.<ref name = block4.1feb/> The exact reason behind the failure was not provided, but officials initially attributed the glitch to easily correctable software issues.<ref name = block4.1feb>{{cite web |url =http://www.defensenews.com/story/defense/land/weapons/2015/02/25/israel-arrow-intercept-target-miss-imdo/24020425/ | work = [[Defense News]] |title= Israel DM: glitch in Arrow 2 missile fixed |first = Noa |last = Amouyal | date =2015-02-25 | accessdate=2015-02-27}}</ref>
====Block-5==== IMDO recently launched initial definition of a new block-5 upgrade to the complete Arrow system that will merge the lower-tier Arrow 2 and exoatmospheric Arrow 3 into a single national missile defense system. According to Arieh Herzog, the planned block-5 will include new ground- and airborne sensors, a [[command and control]] system, and a new target missile – the [[Sparrow target missile|Silver Sparrow]]<ref name=Silver-b5 /> – to simulate potentially nuclear-capable delivery vehicles developed by Iran.<ref name=block5 /> According to the U.S. Missile Defense Agency, block-5 is expected to be able to deal with "more stressing regional threats" by increasing total defended area by some 50 percent.<ref name= Silver-b5>{{cite web | format = Flickr | url = http://farm6.static.flickr.com/5068/5675446608_9a641ccd74_b.jpg |publisher=[[Imaginova]] | work = Space News |title= Israel to develop new Silver Sparrow air-launch target missile | first =Barbara |last= Opall-Rome |date = 2011-04-11 |accessdate= 2011-05-01}}</ref>
The planned block-5 will optimize the existing Super Green Pine radar to operate with the AN/TPY-2 radar as well as with radars commanding anti-ballistic missiles aboard [[United States Navy]] [[destroyer]]s. U.S. radars will be used to support [[Control theory#Closed-loop transfer function|closed-loop]] operations if Israel and U.S. targets in the region come under attack.<ref name=block5 />
===Arrow 3=== {{main article|Arrow 3}} By August 2008 the United States and Israeli governments have initiated development of an upper-tier component to the Israeli Air Defense Command, known as Arrow 3. The development is based on an architecture definition study conducted in 2006–2007, determining the need for the upper-tier component to be integrated into Israel's ballistic missile defense system. According to Arieh Herzog, the main element of this upper tier will be an exoatmospheric interceptor, to be jointly developed by IAI and Boeing.<ref name=dua3>{{cite web |url=http://defense-update.com/products/a/arrow3.html |work=Defense Update|title=Israel, U.S. to embark on collaborative 'upper-tier' missile intercept program to include Arrow 3 and land-based SM-3 missiles |accessdate=2009-08-19}}</ref>
==Specifications== [[File:Arrow missile interceptor cropped.jpg|upright=0.54|thumb|alt=Arrow 2 at the Paris Air Show. |Arrow 2 at the Paris Air Show.]] The Arrow system was originally designed and optimized to intercept short and medium-range ballistic missiles with ranges above {{convert|200|km|mi|abbr=on}}.<ref name="cdi2">{{cite web |url= http://www.cdi.org/program/document.cfm?DocumentID=3596 |publisher=[[Center for Defense Information]] |title= Israel’s missile defense systems: MIA |first=Victoria |last= Samson |date=2006-07-19 |accessdate=2009-10-13}}</ref> It is not intended to intercept either [[military aircraft]] or [[Rocket artillery|artillery rockets]], the second of which are relatively small and short ranged.<ref name="cdi2"/> In contrast to [[Terminal High Altitude Area Defense|THAAD]], [[RIM-161 Standard Missile 3]], and [[MIM-104 Patriot#PAC-3|MIM-104 Patriot PAC-3]], that use kinetic, direct impact to destroy the target ("hit-to-kill") the Arrow 2 relies on explosive detonation.<ref name = mstrt /> Arrow 2 is able to intercept its targets above the [[stratosphere]], high enough so that any nuclear, chemical, or biological weapons do not scatter over Israel.<ref name = mstrt /> The developers' intention was to perform the destruction sequence away from populated locations.<ref name=iafkg/> According to Dr. Uzi Rubin, the missile was tested to determine whether chemical warfare agents would reach the ground should such a warhead be intercepted. The conclusion was that nothing would reach the ground if the warhead is destroyed above the [[jet stream]], which flows from west to east and would therefore blow any chemical residue.<ref group = "Note">Israel borders [[Jordan]] and the [[West Bank]] in the east, and [[Syria]] in the northeast.</ref><ref name = "uzi">{{cite web | url = http://www.jcpa.org/jl/vp493.htm | publisher = [[Jerusalem Center for Public Affairs]] | first = Uzi | last = Rubin | authorlink = Uzi Rubin | title= Beyond Iraq: missile proliferation in the Middle East | date = 2003-03-02 | accessdate = 2009-09-10}}</ref> Nevertheless, Arrow is also capable of low altitude interception, as well as multi-tactical ballistic missiles interception.<ref name="iaibr" />
The two-stage missile is equipped with [[solid propellant]] [[Booster (rocketry)|booster]] and sustainer rocket motors.<ref name=armytec/><ref name=nti2/><ref name="mdaa2"/> The missile uses an initial burn to carry out a vertical hot launch from the container and a secondary burn to sustain the missile's trajectory towards the target at a maximum speed of [[Mach number|Mach]] 9, or {{convert|2.5|km/s|1|abbr=on}}.<ref name=armytec/><ref name = nti2 /><ref name = "mdaa2" /> Thrust vector control is used in the boost and sustainer phases of flight.<ref name = armytec /><ref name=nti2/><ref name="mdaa2"/> At the ignition of the second stage sustainer motor, the first stage assembly separates.<ref name=armytec/><ref name=nti2/><ref name="mdaa2"/> The Arrow missile is launched before the threat missile's trajectory and intercept point are accurately known.<ref name=armytec/><ref name = "mdaa2" /> As more trajectory data becomes available, the optimum intercept point is more precisely defined, towards which the missiles is then guided.<ref name=armytec/><ref name="mdaa2"/> The {{convert |500|kg| abbr = on}} [[kill vehicle]] section of the missile, containing the warhead, fusing and the terminal seeker, is equipped with four moving delta aerodynamic control [[fin]]s to give low altitude interception capability.<ref name= nti2 /> The dual mode missile seeker has a passive infrared seeker for the acquisition and tracking of tactical ballistic missiles and an active radar seeker used to home on air-breathing targets at low altitudes.<ref name = armytec/><ref name= nti2/><ref name= "mdaa2" /> The [[infrared seeker]] is an [[indium antimonide]] [[focal plane]] array.<ref name= armytec/><ref name=nti2/><ref name="mdaa2"/> The kill vehicle is designed to achieve a hit-to-kill interception, but if this is not achieved, the [[proximity fuze]] will direct the warhead fragments at the target shortly before reaching the closest point to the target.<ref name=nti2/> The high explosive directed blast fragmentation warhead is capable of destroying a target within a {{convert|40|-|50|m|ft|abbr= on}} radius.<ref name=global/> In this manner, Arrow also differs from Patriot PAC-3, THAAD, and Standard Missile 3, which rely purely on hit-to-kill technology in which the [[Kinetic energy|kinetic force]] of a precise impact causes the destruction of the threat.<ref name=mstrt />
According to [[Dov Raviv]], a senior developer dubbed "the father of the Arrow anti-ballistic missile",<ref group = "Note">As is Dr. Uzi Rubin: {{Citation | url = http://www.jinsa.org/node/596 | title = Dr. Uzi Rubin, "father" of Israel's Arrow Ballistic Missile Defense System, speaking | publisher = Jewish Institute for National Security Affairs Conference}}.</ref><ref name="father">{{cite web |url= http://archive.globes.co.il/searchgl/Father%20of%20the%20%EF%BF%BDArrow%EF%BF%BD%20missile%20Dov%20Raviv%20believes%20he_s_hd_1L3auD30oN34mC30nDp4vDJCkQ7HjR000.html | work = [[Globes]] | title = Father of the ‘Arrow’ missile Dov Raviv believes he has the answer to Hizbullah’s Katushyas | first = Amnon | last = Barzilai |accessdate=2009-08-23 |date=2007-11-01}}</ref><ref name="father2">{{cite web |url = http://www.jpost.com/Features/Article.aspx?id=8148 | work = [[The Jerusalem Post]] | title = Storm clouds gathering | first=Erik |last= Schechter |accessdate=2011-02-25 |date= 2004 | pp = 38, 40}}</ref><ref name ="dov" /> In case of failure two more interceptors can be launched towards the target at short time intervals.<ref name= mstrt /><ref name="inss" /><ref name="stav" /> If the first of these destroys the target, the second can be directed to another target.<ref name="dov">{{cite web|url=http://www.elec.co.il/Articles/Item.asp?CategoryID=227&ArticleID=3385&VolumeID=15 |work=Electronica |first=Dov |last=Raviv |trans_title=The nuclear threat on Israel – and the Arrow |script-title=he:האיום הגרעיני על ישראל – והחץ |language=he |accessdate=2009-08-19 |date=2004-10-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041124051331/http://www.elec.co.il/Articles/Item.asp?CategoryID=227&ArticleID=3385&VolumeID=15 |archivedate=November 24, 2004 }}</ref> Using this technique, three independent interception possibilities are provided which raise the interception probability from 90 percent to 99.9 percent, thus satisfying the leakage rate requirement.<ref name="stav" /><ref Such capability is currently possessed only by the United States and [[Russia]].<ref name = "father2" /> According to Raviv, the Arrow can discriminate between a warhead and a [[decoy]].<ref Each Arrow battery is equipped with typically four to eight erectors–launchers,<ref name=nti2/> its manning requires about 100 personnel.<ref>{{cite book| last = Cordesman | first = Anthony H. |authorlink= Anthony Cordesman | title =Strategic threats and national missile defenses: defending the U.S. homeland |page=359 | publisher = [[Center for Strategic and International Studies]] |location= [[Washington, D.C.]] | year = 2002 | isbn = 0-275-97425-1 | url = https://books.google.com/?id=VsylMAAB2poC |accessdate=2009-09-12}}</ref> Each [[Trailer (vehicle)|trailer]]-mounted erector–launcher weighs {{convert |35|t|lb}}<ref name = "Egozi2">{{cite web | url =http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2003/07/29/169425/arrow-in-waiting.html | work = [[Flightglobal.com|Flight global]] |title=Arrow in waiting |first=Arie |last= Egozi |date=2003-07-29 | accessdate = 2009-09-12}} See also weight overprint on each canister: [http://picasaweb.google.com/avigolden/2005_12_29MisdarKnafaimInBeerShevaWithAssaf#5337302703676775858 #1], [http://picasaweb.google.com/avigolden/2005_12_29MisdarKnafaimInBeerShevaWithAssaf#5337302715540310706 #2].</ref> when loaded with six launch tubes with ready-to-fire missiles.<ref name=armytec/><ref name=nti2/> After firing the launchers can be reloaded in an hour.<ref name=armytec/><ref name="mdaa2"/> The system is transportable rather than mobile, as it can be moved to other prepared sites, but cannot be set up just anywhere.<ref name="Egozi2"/>

===Green Pine=== {{main article|EL/M-2080 Green Pine}} [[File:EL-M-2080 Super Green Pine.gif|thumb|"Super Green Pine" radar antenna.|alt="Super Green Pine" radar antenna.]] [[File:Arrow system.jpg|upright=1.85|thumb|Stages of missile interception by the Arrow system. The picture shows a hostile missile trajectory and that of the "[[Sparrow target missile|Black Sparrow]]" air-launched target missile used in firing tests.|alt=Stages of missile interception by the Arrow system. The picture shows a hostile missile trajectory and that of the "Black Sparrow" air-launched target missile used in firing tests.]] The "Green Pine" is an [[active electronically scanned array]] (AESA) solid state radar operating at [[L band]] in the range 500 [[MHz]] to 1,000 MHz,<ref name= armytec/><ref name= Bar-Joseph>{{Harvnb | Bar-Joseph | 2001 | pp = 153–54}}</ref><ref name="elta">{{cite web |publisher =[[Israel Aerospace Industries]] |accessdate = 2012-08-04 |url= http://www.iai.co.il/17660-27136-en/BusinessAreas_Elta_SpaceSystems_GreenPine.aspx |title= EL/M-2080 "Green Pine" radar system}}</ref> or 1,000 MHz to 2,000 MHz.<ref name="gpj">{{cite web |url=http://www.janes.com/articles/Janes-Radar-and-Electronic-Warfare-Systems/EL-M2080-Green-Pine-Israel.html |publisher=[[Jane's Information Group]] |title=EL/M-2080 'Green Pine' (Israel), battlefield, missile control and ground surveillance radar systems |date=2009-10-30 |accessdate=2009-08-26}}</ref> It operates in search, detection, tracking, and missile guidance modes simultaneously.<ref name=armytec/><ref name="gpj"/> It is capable of detecting targets at ranges of up to about {{convert|500|km|mi|abbr=on}} and is able to track more than 30 targets at speeds over {{convert|3000|m/s|-3|abbr=on}}.<ref name=armytec/><ref name=aw-2012-a3>{{cite web |first=David |last=Fulghum |url=http://www.aviationweek.com/Article.aspx?id=/article-xml/AW_09_03_2012_p40-490727.xml |publisher=[[Aviation Week & Space Technology]] |title=Higher-altitude Arrow design to show its potential |date=2012-09-03 |accessdate=2012-09-03}}</ref> The radar illuminates the target and guides the Arrow missile to within {{convert|4|m|ft|abbr=on}} of the target.<ref name=armytec/><ref name="gpj2">{{cite web |url=http://www.janes.com/articles/Janes-Electronic-Mission-Aircraft/EL-M2083-Israel.html |publisher=[[Jane's Information Group]] |title=EL/M-2083 (Israel), payloads |date=2009-04-09 |accessdate=2009-10-12}}</ref>
;Super Green Pine An advanced version of the radar, called "Super Green Pine",<ref name="iaia3">{{cite web|url=http://www.iai-global.com/32981-39666-en/default.aspx?PageNum=2 |publisher=[[Israel Aerospace Industries]] |title=IAI develops Arrow 3 interceptor in response to longer range threats |date=2009-06-10 |accessdate=2009-08-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110712234335/http://www.iai-global.com/32981-39666-en/default.aspx?PageNum=2 |archivedate=2011-07-12 |df= }}</ref> "Green Pine" Block-B,<ref name="sk3">{{cite web |url=https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2009/09/113_52006.html |publisher=''[[The Korea Times]]''|first=Jung |last=Sung-ki |title=Israeli radar chosen for missile defense |date=2009-09-17 |accessdate=2009-09-17}}</ref> or "Great Pine" ({{lang-he|אורן אדיר}}, {{IPA-he|oʁen adiʁ|pron}}), is to take the place of the original "Green Pine. As of 2008 both versions were active.<ref name="syria3">{{cite web |url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1012826.html |first=Yuval |last= Azoulay |publisher= ''Haaretz'' |title=Report: Syria test fires series of long-range missiles |date=2008-08-18 |accessdate=2009-09-10}}</ref> The "Super Green Pine" extends detection range to about {{convert|800|-|900|km|mi|abbr=on}}.<ref name="sk3"/><ref name = iai-boeing-a3>{{cite web |first = Alon |last = Ben David| authorlink= Alon Ben David | url = http://www.aviationweek.com/Article.aspx?id=/article-xml/asd_01_26_2012_p01-02-418074.xml | work = [[Aviation Week & Space Technology]] | title = Boeing links up with IAI on Arrow-3 | date = 2012-01-26 | accessdate = 2012-01-27}}</ref> An even more advanced upgrade of the Super Green Pine is under development.<ref name=aw-2012-a3/>
===Golden Citron=== The "Golden Citron" ({{lang-he|אתרוג זהב}}, {{IPA-he|etʁoɡ zahav|pron}}) truck-mounted [[net-centric]] [[open systems architecture]]<ref name="iaibr"/> Battle Management Command, Control, Communication & Intelligence Center<ref name=tests/> can control up to 14 intercepts simultaneously.<ref name=armytec/><ref name=nti2/> As of 2007 it was one of the world's most advanced net-centric systems.<ref name="defup"/> The system provides fully automatic as well as [[Human-in-the-Loop]] options at every stage<ref name="elisra"/> of battle operation management.<ref name="iaibr">{{cite web |url=http://www.iai.co.il/sip_storage/files/6/34766.pdf |format=PDF |publisher=[[Israel Aerospace Industries]] |title=Arrow brochure |accessdate=2009-08-19}}</ref> It is also capable of interoperability with other theater missile defense systems and [[C4ISTAR|C<sup>3</sup>I]] systems.<ref name="elisra">{{cite web |url=http://www.elisra.com/solutionShow.asp?cat=171 |publisher=[[Elisra]] |title=Citron Tree BMD Command, Control, Battle Management & Communication (C2BMC) |accessdate=2014-01-10}}</ref> Notably [[Link 16]], [[TADIL-J]], communications were being altered to allow interoperability with Patriot fire control units. Assigned targets can be handed over to the Patriot's [[MIM-104 Patriot#The AN/MPQ-53 and AN/MPQ-65 Radar Set|AN/MPQ-53]] fire control radar. Tests carried out by the U.S and Israel have successfully linked the Arrow with both U.S and Israeli versions of the Patriot.<ref name=armytec/><ref name=nti2 />
The "Citron Tree" has three banks of operator consoles laid out in a U shape. In the center sits the [[Officer (armed forces)|officer]] in command who oversees the engagement, but also has links to the other parts of the battery as well as to IAF [[headquarters]]. On the commander's right sits the engagement officer, who ensures that targets are assigned to other engagement officers sitting on the right-hand leg of the U. Each is assigned a geographical area to defend and two of the officers are more senior as they have an overview of Patriot batteries. To the left of the commander is the resource officer, who monitors the status and readiness of the missiles. On the left of the U sits the sky picture officer, who is in contact with the [[Home Front Command]] and uses the center's ability to predict impact point to alert the [[Civil defense in Israel|civil authorities]]. Also at these consoles are an [[Intelligence (information gathering)|intelligence]] officer and an [[After Action Review|after-action]]/[[Debriefing|debrief]] officer, who uses recordings as it is impossible to absorb all the information during engagements.<ref name="Egozi2"/> All in all, the "Golden Citron" is manned by 7–10 operators.<ref name=Bar-Joseph />
===Brown Hazelnut=== The "Brown Hazelnut" ({{lang-he|אגוז חום}}, {{IPA-he |eɡoz χum|pron}}) launch control center is located at the launch site,<ref name = "iaibr"/> up to {{convert|300|km|mi|abbr = on}} from the "Golden Citron" fire control center.<ref name= armytec /><ref name = "mdaa2" /> It employs [[microwave]] and [[radio]] data and voice communications links to the "Green Pine" and "Golden Citron". The launch method is a vertical hot launch from a sealed canister,<ref name= "iaibr" /> providing all-[[azimuth]] coverage.<ref name = "iaibr" /> "Brown Hazelnut" also has missile maintenance and diagnostic capabilities.<ref name ="iaibr" />
==Production== [[File:Arrow coverage.png|thumb|upright=1.2|alt=Coverage of Israel provided by two Arrow 2 batteries, derived from their published locations (Palmachim, Ein Shemer) and range (90–100 km). |Coverage of Israel provided by two Arrow 2 batteries, derived from their published locations (Palmachim, Ein Shemer) and range (90–100 km).]] Israel initially produced the Arrow system domestically,<ref group="Note">Except for Lockheed Martin's active radar seeker.</ref> but on February 11, 2003 IAI and Boeing signed an agreement, valued at over $25 million for fiscal years 2003–2004,<ref name=boeing>{{cite web |url=http://www.boeing.com/defense-space/space/arrow/docs/Arrow_overview.pdf |format=PDF|publisher=Boeing |title=Arrow II brochure |accessdate=2009-08-19 |date=March 2008}}</ref> to establish production facilities for the manufacture of components for the Arrow missile in the United States. In March 2004, IAI awarded a $78 million production contract to Boeing; the total contract value could exceed $225 million through second quarter 2008.<ref name=boeing/> As a result of successful implementation of this contract Boeing is responsible for production of about 35 percent of Arrow missile components, including the electronics section, booster motor case and missile canister,<ref name=boeing/> at its [[Huntsville, Alabama]] facilities.<ref name=opalrome/> IAI, the prime contractor of the Arrow system, is responsible for integration and the final assembly of the Arrow missile in Israel.<ref name=tests/> Boeing also coordinates the production of Arrow missile components manufactured by more than 150 American companies located in over 25 states.<ref name=boeing150>{{cite web |url=http://www.boeing.com/news/releases/2003/q1/nr_030211m.htm |publisher=Boeing |title=Israel Aircraft Industries and Boeing sign an agreement to establish production infrastructure to manufacture Arrow missile components in the United State |accessdate=2009-10-12 |date=2003-02-11}}</ref> Boeing delivered its first Arrow 2 interceptor to Israel in 2005.<ref name=mstrt/><ref name=boeing/> Co-produced interceptors has been tested since February 12, 2007.<ref name="mda2">{{cite web |url=http://www.mda.mil/global/documents/pdf/07fyi0096.pdf |format=PDF |publisher=Missile Defense Agency |title=U.S./Israel complete successful Arrow missile defense test|date=2007-02-12 |accessdate=2009-11-04}}</ref> Final deliveries to the Israel Air Force were planned by the end of 2010.<ref name=block5/>
Other major contractors are: * [[Elta]] – produces the "Green Pine" / "Super Green Pine" radar;<ref name="elta"/> * [[Elisra]] – produces the "Golden Citron" [[C4ISTAR|C<sup>3</sup>I]] Center;<ref name="elisra"/> * [[Rafael Advanced Defense Systems]] – produces the sustainer motor and the warhead;<ref name=armytec/><ref name="mdaa2"/> * [[Israel Military Industries]] – produces the booster motor;<ref name=armytec/> * [[Alliant Techsystems]] – produces the motor cases and the first stage [[nozzle]];<ref name=armytec/><ref name="mdaa2"/> * [[Lockheed Martin]] – produces the active radar seeker;<ref name="mda3">{{cite web |url=http://www.mda.mil/global/documents/pdf/00archive0010.pdf |publisher=Missile Defense Agency |format=PDF |title=Arrow weapons system successful intercept |date=2000-09-14 |accessdate=2009-11-04}}</ref> * [[Raytheon]] – produces the infrared seeker;<ref name=nti2/><ref name="mda3" /> * [[Ceradyne]] – produces the [[ceramic]] [[radome]].<ref name="cera">{{cite web |url=http://www.ceradyne-thermo.com/uploads/Radome_White_Paper_PDF.pdf |format=PDF |publisher=[[Ceradyne]] |title=Ceramic radomes for tactical missile systems |accessdate=2011-04-13}}</ref>
==Deployment== According to its original 1986 schedule, the Arrow system was supposed to enter operational service in 1995.<ref name=global/> The first operational Arrow battery was deployed, however, in March 2000 in [[Palmachim Airbase]], near the city of [[Rishon LeZion]], south of the [[Tel Aviv]] [[metropolitan area]]. It was declared operational in October 2000, and reached its full capacity in March 2001.<ref name="video">{{cite web |url=http://www.iai.co.il/sip_storage/files/6/34806.wmv |format=WMV |publisher=[[Israel Aerospace Industries]] |author=Israel Missile Defense Organization and United States Ballistic Missile Defense Organization |title=Arrow missile}}</ref> Deployment of the second battery at [[Ein Shemer]] ([[Ein Shemer Airfield]]),<ref name=mstrt/> near the city of [[Hadera]], [[Haifa District]], northern Israel, was delayed by strong opposition from local residents who feared its radar would be hazardous to their health.<ref name=global/> The situation was eventually resolved and Israel's second battery completed its deployment, turned operational and linked up with first battery in October 2002. In 2007 the IDF has reportedly decided to modify its missile defense doctrine and in order to counter possible Syrian and Iranian missile [[Barrage (artillery)|barrages]] and has quietly modified its deployment of the Arrow in northern Israel.<ref name=change>{{cite web |url=http://www.jpost.com/Home/Article.aspx?id=73129 |publisher=''[[The Jerusalem Post]]'' |title=IDF modifying Arrow deployment in the North |first=Yaakov |last= Katz |date=2007-08-23 |accessdate=2010-07-27}}</ref>
The IDF planned to procure 50<ref name=sipri />–100 interceptors for each battery.<ref name=mstrt/> As of 1998, a battery was estimated to cost about $170 million.<ref name=global/><ref name="batcost">{{cite web|url=http://www.wisconsinproject.org/countries/israel/missile2000.htm |publisher=[[Wisconsin Project on Nuclear Arms Control]] |title=Israel missile update – 2000 |year=2000 |accessdate=2009-09-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100328164425/http://www.wisconsinproject.org:80/countries/israel/missile2000.htm |archivedate=2010-03-28 |df= }}</ref><ref group="Note">With four launchers.</ref> As of 2012, reportedly one "Great Pine" radar is deployed alongside two "Green Pine" radars.<ref name=iai-boeing-a3/>
Israel had originally planned to deploy two Arrow 2 batteries but has since sought and won promises of funding for a third battery.<ref name=global/> Some reports stated that a third battery was already deployed,<ref name="inss" /> or in development in the south,<ref name=mstrt/> while others claimed that a decision on deployment of a third battery has not yet been made, although it was under discussion for service entry in 2012.<ref name=armytec/><ref name=nti/><ref name=global/> Another report stated that Israel planned to deploy not one, but two additional Arrow 2 batteries to defend the country's southern region, also covering sensitive sites such as the Negev Nuclear Research Center.<ref name="a3-80"/> However the decision about the third battery was taken in October 2010.<ref name ="third battery">{{cite web |url=http://dover.idf.il/IDF/English/News/Tech/10/10/1402.htm |first=Bar Josephine |last=Dadon |publisher=''[[Bamahane]]'' |title=A third antimissile battery on its way | accessdate = 2010-10-14 |date= 2010-10-14| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101016165248/http://dover.idf.il/IDF/English/News/Tech/10/10/1402.htm| archivedate= 16 October 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The new battery was expected to be put into operational use in 2012 in the center of the country.<ref name= "third battery2012">{{cite web |url=http://www.idf.il/1086-14882-EN/Dover.aspx |first= Shir Aharon |last= Bram | publisher =[[Israel Defense Forces]] |title=Arrow missile defense battery to be deployed in central Israel | accessdate = 2012-03-13 |date= 2012-02-13}}</ref> According to ''[[Jane's Defence Weekly]]'', some sources indicate that the new Arrow 2 battery became operational in 2012 in an Israeli Air Force facility at [[Tal Shahar]], roughly halfway between [[Jerusalem]] and [[Ashdod]], near [[Beit Shemesh]].<ref name= "janesTalShahar">{{cite web |url=http://farm8.staticflickr.com/7443/8910085466_b8037e498f_o.jpg |first=Jeremy |last=Binnie | publisher =[[Jane's Information Group]] |title=Israeli BMD facility details revealed |year=2013 |accessdate = 2013-06-01}}</ref>
===Export=== Apart from Israel no country has purchased a full Arrow system, although [[India]] had acquired and deployed three "Green Pine" radars by August 2005.<ref name="india">{{cite web |url = http://www.globalsecurity.org/wmd/world/india/bmd.htm |first=John E |last=Pike |authorlink = John E. Pike | work = Global Security |title= India: ballistic missile defense |accessdate=2009-08-26| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090910092112/http://www.globalsecurity.org/wmd/world/india/bmd.htm | archivedate= 10 September 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl = no}}</ref> The [[Indian government]] has sought to purchase the Arrow system since 1999,<ref name = dtic /> however in early 2002 the U.S. vetoed Israel's request to sell the Arrow 2 missiles to India,<ref name= global /><ref name="india" /> exercising its right as a major funding contributor.<ref>{{cite book| last = Assamann | first = Lars| title =Theater missile defense in East Asia: implications for Beijing and Tokyo | publisher = [[Transaction Publishers]]| year = 2007| isbn = 978-3-8258-0223-3 | page=205 |url = https://books.google.com/?id=jyM2hhUlfD8C | accessdate = 2009-09-12}}</ref> U.S. officials argued that the sale would violate the [[Missile Technology Control Regime]] (MTCR).<ref name=global/> Although the Arrow 2 could possibly achieve a range of {{convert |300|km|mi|abbr=on}}, it is designed for intercepts at shorter ranges, and it is unclear whether it could carry a {{convert |500|kg|abbr=on}} payload to this range specified in the MTCR.<ref name = global /> In 2011 once again an [[Indian Army]] official said that the Arrow 2 might become part of India's missile defense solution.<ref>{{cite web |title =Rafael in $1b Indian anti-tank missile deal | first = Ran | last = Dagoni |url = http://www.globes.co.il/serveen/globes/docview.asp?did=1000633160&fid=1725 | work = [[Globes]] | date =2011-03-24 | accessdate= 2011-03-24}}</ref>
[[Turkey]] also planned to buy anti-missile air defense systems worth more than $1 billion. The Arrow was considered a potential contender,<ref name= turkey>{{cite web |url = http://www.defensenews.com/story.php?i=3927941 | work = [[Defense News]] |title= Turk–Israeli deals threatened by Gaza |first1 = Umit | last1 = Enginsoy | last2=Bekdil | first2 = Burak Ege |date= 2009-02-02 |accessdate=2009-08-22}}</ref> but was rejected on political grounds.<ref>{{Citation | url = http://dmilt.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=6028:turkey-re-launch-and-new-clauses-to-the-t-loramids-tender&catid=3:asia&Itemid=56 | title = Turkey; Re-launch and new clauses to the T-LORAMIDS tender | publisher = Dmilt | date = March 23, 2013}}.</ref> In the past, the [[United Kingdom]], [[Japan]], and [[Singapore]] were mentioned as then potential foreign customers of the Arrow system.<ref name=dtic /><ref name= global /> [[Netherlands]] reportedly expressed interest in the "Golden Citron" [[C4ISTAR|C<sup>3</sup>I]] center in November 1999.<ref name=dtic />
In the late 1990s officials of [[Jordan]] have expressed concern that any conflagration between Israel and Iraq or Iran would impact its territory. The problem becomes more difficult for Jordan when the warheads are not conventional. Therefore, [[Benjamin Netanyahu]], during his first term of office as Prime Minister of Israel, reportedly offered Jordan "a defensive umbrella of Arrow 2". Without allowing Israel to forward deploy the Arrow launchers close to the Iraqi border, the other option is for Israel to sell Jordan the Arrow system. This is most likely what Prime Minister Netanyahu meant above. In May 1999 Israel reportedly requested U.S. approval for selling Arrow batteries to Jordan, but apparently no such approval has been given yet.<ref name=dtic>{{cite web | first = Guermantes E. |last=Lailari | title = Israel's national missile defense strategy | format = PDF | publisher = [[Defense Technical Information Center]] | date = April 2001 | url = http://www.dtic.mil/cgi-bin/GetTRDoc?AD=ADA407050&Location=U2&doc=GetTRDoc.pdf | accessdate = 2009-09-22 }}</ref>
Armed with marketing approval by their respective governments, a U.S.–Israeli industrial team plans to offer the Arrow system to [[South Korea]]. The potential deal, estimated to exceed $1 billion.<ref name = a3-sk>{{cite web | url = http://www.defensenews.com/article/20120130/DEFREG04/301300005/IAI-Boeing-Ready-Arrow-Export-8212-S-Korea-? | work = [[Defense News]] |title= IAI, Boeing ready Arrow for export — to S. Korea? |first = Barbara | last = Opall-Rome |date=2012-01-30 |accessdate= 2012-01-31}}</ref>
For the United States, the Arrow has provided important technical and operational data.<ref name="jewish" /><ref name ="mda3" /> It remains a key element in the Missile Defense Agency’s plan for a layered missile defense architecture, and an example of a successful, affordable program. At the moment, however, the United States does not have any plans to procure and deploy the Arrow.<ref name=mstrt/> Nevertheless, in September 2009 the Arrow system was mentioned by then U.S. [[United States Secretary of Defense|Secretary of Defense]] [[Robert Gates]] and then [[Vice Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff]] [[General (United States)|General]] [[James Cartwright]] among the alternative to the proposed [[US missile defense complex in Poland|U.S. missile defense assets in Europe]].<ref name="europe">{{cite web |url= http://www.defenselink.mil/transcripts/transcript.aspx?transcriptid=4479 |publisher=[[United States Department of Defense]] |title=DoD news briefing with secretary Gates and Gen. Cartwright from the Pentagon | accessdate= 2009-09-18 | date= 2009-09-17 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20091007212006/http://www.defenselink.mil/transcripts/transcript.aspx?transcriptid=4479 | archivedate= 7 October 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref name = "europe2">{{cite web |url= http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3778586,00.html | work = Ynet news | publisher =[[Associated Press]] |title=US says forces to employ Israeli 'Arrow' in missile system |accessdate = 2009-09-18 |date = 2009-09-17}}</ref> The Arrow system is being incorporated into U.S. anti-ballistic capability in [[Europe]], they said.<ref name="europe" />
In a June 2011 interview [[Lieutenant General]] [[Patrick J. O'Reilly]] said that Arrow 2 will be integrated into a regional defense array planned by the U.S. in the [[Middle East]]. According to the interview, it may also protect Arab countries who are allies of the U.S. but with which Israel has no diplomatic ties.<ref name= "arrow-arab">{{cite web | title =U.S.: Israeli missile defense system can protect our Mideast bases | work = [[Haaretz]] | first=Anshel |last= Pfeffer | accessdate=2011-06-20 | url = http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/u-s-israeli-missile-defense-system-can-protect-our-mideast-bases-1.368755}}</ref> By October 2015, the countries of the [[Gulf Cooperation Council]] (GCC) had become interested in procuring the Arrow system for themselves.<ref>[http://armyrecognition.com/october_2015_global_defense_security_news_uk/gulf_countries_interested_in_israeli_air_defence_systems_41510154.html Gulf countries interested in Israeli air defence systems] - Armyrecognition.com, 15 October 2015</ref>
